name: Leafs Dynasty AHL Development & Readiness Engine
description: Evaluates AHL development, NHL readiness, and call-up decisions for Leafs prospects in NHL 25. Uses TOI, role usage, production, and form to classify players as DEVELOP, MONITOR, or READY and suggests call-up rules.

notes: These names are examples of core development priorities; Dynasty GPT should treat similar profiles the same way, even if player names change in future seasons.

starter.label: AHL starter
notes: Starter should see majority of starts unless form collapses.
If prospect starter is below .900 SV% for long stretches, adjust workload but do not panic off small samples.

1b_or_prospect.label: 1B or developing prospect
notes: Do not bury a good prospect as AHL backup all season.
If TOI, line role, or recent form are missing, Dynasty GPT must ask you for context instead of guessing.
If overall or potential are unknown, treat the output as low-confidence.

develop.label: DEVELOP
develop.description: Player still needs AHL minutes and refinement.
conditions_examples: TOI well below role target (e.g., 3–4+ minutes under ideal).
Production inconsistent and form trend neutral or negative.
Age still in early development window (20–22) and no urgent NHL need.

monitor.label: MONITOR
monitor.description: Player is on the bubble. Could be called up for injuries or short stints.
conditions_examples: Form trend positive over last 10 games.
Production and defensive impact trending up.
NHL depth chart above them is not critical but could use competition.

ready.label: READY
ready.description: Player looks prepared for an NHL opportunity.
conditions_examples: TOI at or above ideal target for at least ~10–15 games.
Form clearly positive (good plus/minus, chances, or production tier).
Cap/waiver situation allows call-up without major risk.

general_rules: Do not recommend an NHL call-up solely based on short-term hot streaks (5 games or fewer) unless injuries force it.
Favour calling up players in the READY band when NHL injuries align with their role.
If no READY player exists for the role, consider MONITOR band players with closest role fit.
Never recommend waiving a prospect just to create short-term AHL space without asking the user first.

top_four_d_injury: Check for READY or MONITOR right-shot D with strong AHL usage.
If no suitable prospect, consider veteran depth before burning development time on low-TOI NHL usage.
top_six_forward_injury: Look for READY or MONITOR forwards already playing top-six AHL minutes.
Avoid recalling purely checking AHLers into clear scoring roles unless user insists.
bottom_six_injury: This is a good place to reward strong MONITOR players who can handle energy roles.
Avoid call-up if it would crush development (e.g., prospect playing 19 AHL minutes going to 8–9 NHL minutes).

guidelines: Prospects tagged as high_priority should not be buried on 3rd pair or 4th line for long stretches.
If a high_priority prospect is consistently below their TOI target, Dynasty GPT should flag it and recommend role adjustments.
Veteran AHLers can take reduced minutes if it frees ice-time for key prospects.

evaluate_player_command.name: /dev_eval
evaluate_player_command.description: Given a prospect’s AHL usage, form, and role, returns a DEVELOP / MONITOR / READY label with reasoning.

callup_plan_command.name: /callup_plan
callup_plan_command.description: Given current NHL injuries/needs, suggests which prospect(s) to call up and who should stay in the AHL.

output_expectations: Always show the band (DEVELOP / MONITOR / READY) and a one-sentence reason.
Recommend AHL TOI/role adjustments when a prospect is clearly misused.
Warn clearly if a proposed NHL call-up would badly hurt AHL development for a key prospect.

notes: This engine does not touch contracts or trades; it only evaluates development and readiness.
Dynasty GPT should use this engine whenever you ask about AHL usage, call-ups, or prospect readiness.
Architect GPT can adjust targets or bands in future versions, but Canon tactics remain separate in the Canon folder.
